label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, May 13, 1944
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, discussing the last letter she received from him, her love and hate relationship with Medway Plantation, and her life in London, England.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
R 5 22 44
May 13th
Dear Sidney,
I loved that description of Armant taking his phisical e xam.
Is that because he wants to go to sea? I suppose he will do it too if he
has made up his mind. I cant understand his not loving Hawaii the way you
both do. That heavenly sea with the sunsets, flowering trees and bushes,
and lovely soft air. You make a wonderful picture of it to read[,]and I can
almost visualize how heavemnly it really is.
I roared with laughter over Henry's tale of woe about the
plantation. Everything fallen down, broken down and disintergrating.
What a place! Only Mr. Baruch hangs on and goes there. Maybe he has the[s]ecret
of how it should be handles. I dont know. It sounds like one long lagubrious
headache to me. The explosions that cause the plaster to fall, the telehone
poles rotting, the banks breaking, the bull over worked etc etc. I really
thought it a very funny letter as I cant possibl[y] immagine being able t
think of anything else that could go wrong. Everything about it is wrong
except one thing. It has Beauty- real beauty, the sun comming through the
mist behind those big oaks on the lawn in the morning, the shadows, the
drifting wisps of moss,and the shadows on the house in the evening. I know
Hawaii is far more beautiful and one would soon attach oneself to a new
house. I only feel in my heart how much effort, thought, pain and time I
have devoted to that house. The work to get the paneling up, the furniture
in, the walls painted, the garden built, the vegetables planted. I somehow
feel we made an attractive place out of nothing from scratch[,]and if we sell
it we throw out the window every shred of association of ourselves with Medway.
It is sort of hard to explain what I mean. We fixed the smoke house, the
school house, the guest house. It was all our idea, a bit of us that took
years to get that way. However I am sure I am wrong about feeling anything
at all about that plac-e as it is not practical, it is desperately expensive,
it is impossible to keep repaired etc etc. I believ[e]have it as a shooting
lodge, sell timber off it every year selectively. We'll have a plane and
fly down there any week end[,]and really have a house with our nice furniture
[what is left of it] moved to a house that can be kept in repair,in a place
where you can get things done easily and where everything does n't mildew
disintergrate and fall apart. Hawaii sounds such heaven to me. It is every
thing I love most in the world. To live in slacks and shorts, to lie on a
beach - to wallow in that water, to live in a house covered with flowering
vines and to have plenty of sunshine all day long- Yes Darling that sounds
heaven but I would n't want to be right in a town like Honolulu. It would
have to be away wh-ere you dont see other peoples roofs- dont you think so?
I suppose you dont know the islands around? You know we will all fly which
will make life so different to get about.
After days of heavenly spring weather it has turned cold
again[,]and damp[,]and dreary[,]and as I am in my office to day SUNDAY working
as any other day I dont really mind being inside as it is no day for golf.
However the office looks shoddy and dirty to return to this morning and
[End Page 1]
2
I would certainly ra[t]her be in bed and sound asleep. I feel very tired as
my assistant is off on a holliday,and this week Ihave had three ten hour
days in a row and now Sunday. Well if we can just get the war through and
over with thats all that matters. You ought to see the way these British
girls work. Pan Martin a British Red Cross driver came to dinner last night
she had been up since 5 A.M. driving[,]and arrived at 9 c'clock for dinner
as she had to wait fo[r] a train at a station that came in late. Believe me
those girls really work. They all look tired too. When you board a train
for anywhere their heads nod and roll[,]and soon everyone in the carriageis
asleep. I have seen people miss their sta[T]ions unless someone wakes themup.
They look pale and exhausted[,]and ofcourse the trains are so crouded it is
unbelievable. Women do all the station work, call in trains, carry bags,
take tickets etc etc. everywhere women in uniform. Believe me its impresive,
and I never get over feeling it.
There is a delightful story about Grosvenor Square[there are
dozens] but this is a,conversation between Oncle Jo, Winston and F.D.R.
The conversation is about teritorial ambitions. To R.D.R. says the U.S.
has none,and Winston says "You promise to give Grosvenor Square back tothe
British when the war is over?"
"An Englishman spoke on Grosvenor Square" is the take of f
on that poem of "A nightingale sang in Berkeley Square". I have no more
little quips for you I am afraid,and no story as good as Armants about
the little boy asking where he came from.
I lunched to-day around the corner at Clar----- and saw
Serge, Mike Phipps, and alot fo Generals. Had a delicious lunch of fish
pilaf, roast pork ans spinach[,]and plenty of larger beer. I am now back
in the office but there is little going on as very few people are on board.
Take care of yourself and get those ribs of yours meanded.
I dont know how long this good mail service will keep up
but lets hope it goes on[,]for it makes letter writing much more fun when
thye arrive w[a]rm instead of old and stone cold if you know what I mean.
I always feel I am telling you about things so long in the past that it
lacks interest. Your letters have such wonderful descriptions in them that
they can give one a thrill an[y] time, and I just love hearing from you my
darling.
With loads of love to you my doodles-
Gertrude S Legendre
The kids must be on their way north by
now - I am sure they will love
Watch Hill -
[End Page 2]
